signature_drinks.name: Swiss White Wine
signature_drinks.description: Local Swiss wines, particularly whites from the Zurich wine region. Switzerland produces excellent wines rarely exported, making them a local treasure.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with Z√ºrcher Geschnetzeltes and other cream-based dishes. The white wine in the dish itself is often the same wine served alongside.

signature_drinks.name: Rivella
signature_drinks.description: Switzerland's unique national soft drink made from milk whey. A distinctly Swiss beverage with a slightly herbal, refreshing taste.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Casual drinking, often chosen by locals over international sodas. Represents Swiss innovation and local pride.

food_culture_notes: Traditional Swiss food in Zurich has German, Austrian, and French roots due to equidistance from those borders
'Nach Z√ºrcher Art' (Zurich-style) typically means: meat, potatoes, mushrooms, butter, and cream - German heartiness with French saucy influence
Zurich dining combines elegance with tradition - historic guild houses (Zunfthaus) and armories converted to restaurants
Reservations essential for popular Swiss restaurants, especially Friday/Saturday evenings - they fill up quickly
The city offers fondue and raclette year-round at restaurants like Swiss Chuchi
Portions at traditional spots like Zeughauskeller are famously generous - 'the portions are no joke!'
High ceilings, long wooden tables, and lively buzz characterize traditional dining atmosphere
